title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: It is recorded that Scott spent much time with him one summer at his house in Melville Street, Portobello. He was at No. 23 Maitland Street, a few doors from Athol Crescent, in 18 18, and a letter of his to Hogg was addressed from No. 25 Northumberland Street in 1821 ; but in his own correspondence, and in that of his friends, and in the printed gossip of his contem poraries, no hint is given as to any other of his local habitations. Naturally he was often in Scott's vari ous houses, and a guest at all of the tables of all of the men of his own charming coterie.

title: The life and correspondence of Andrew Combe ...
author: Combe, George
snippet: On the 25th September 1833 George Combe was married to Miss Cecilia Siddons, and removed to Charlotte Square, leaving Dr Combe and Miss Cox in possession of the house in Northumberland Street, in which they had previously lived together.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: Once he offered his services to a Conservative statesman ; at another time he shot himself in the coat in Northumberland Street, Strand, to oblige an evening paper (five shillings).

title: The life and correspondence of Andrew Combe ...
author: Combe, George
snippet: In consequence of the increasing success of George and Andrew Combe in their several professions, they left their residence in Brown Square, and in May 1827 removed to No. 25 Northumberland Street, in the New Town.

title: Letters of Asa Gray,
author: Gray, Asa
snippet: Saturday evening, January 19. I am now in lodgings, No. 36 Northumberland Street, near Northumberland House, Charing Cross, in the room just vacated by Dr. Richardson ; sixteen shillings a week, and a shilling for my breakfast when I choose to take it here. It is half past eleven.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: In Northumberland Street—-this and others I shall mention are short narrow streets or lanes leading off the Strand—lived Ben Jonson with his step-father, a bricklayer, and in Craven Street Dr. Benjamin Franklin resided in 1771. Charles Mathews, the comedian, was born in the Strand.

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: almost from Macintyre's door. Ogilvie resided in Northumberland Street, while his friend had to walk right out to the Grange, via the Lothian Road, Bruntsfield Links, and Whitehouse Loan.

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: They were chiefly populated by lodging-house keepers like Mrs. Lirriper, by rather shady private hotels, by struggling solicitors with a sprinkling of usurers, and by cook-shops. It was an innovation when George Smith started the Pall Mall Gazette, a West End journal, 'written by gentlemen for gentlemen,' bringing life and briskness into Northumberland Street, which nevertheless was still a cul-de-sac. Since the brothers Adam built the Adelphi, which proved a financial failure, the builder and educated architect had found little to do in that quarter.

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: Stephen, a legist by profession, with a legal and logical intellect, was a journalist by predilection. He used to say he would rather represent Northumberland Street than any constituency in the kingdom. Reluctantly he accepted a lucrative post in the East, but he hated Calcutta, never ceased to be homesick, and when he took his welcome release, hurried home like a schoolboy for the holidays.

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: Reluctantly he accepted a lucrative post in the East, but he hated Calcutta, never ceased to be homesick, and when he took his welcome release, hurried home like a schoolboy for the holidays. A telegram from Southampton announcing his arrival to Northumberland Street, asked that next morning a boy should be sent as formerly for copy to his chambers in the Temple. The boy may have been sent, but in Stephen's absence Maine had stepped into his place as leading leader writer.

title: Memoirs and correspondence of Francis Horner, M.P.
author: Horner, Francis
snippet: I was beginning to blame you for not writing ; and nothing has prevented me this week from writing to you, but military services. James Brougham and I joined the Bloomsbury Association ; and for ten days past have been drilling most indefatigably; going from Northumberland Street up to the Foundling Hospital Ground twice every day. I have been at it three hours this morning, and my hand shakes so, that you see I cannot write.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: " To J. G. Lochhart, Esq., Northumberland Street, Edinburgh.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: *'• To J. G. Lockhart, Esq., Northumberland Street
